author: Jill Margo
title: How to get off the slow path to dementia
text:
The brain, the most metabolically active organ in the body, consumes between 10 and 20 per cent of its energy stores. iStock Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Jill Margo Among the many paths to dementia, there's a slow one that thousands of Australian men are already on.
It begins innocuously with a pressured work life which leaves little time for self-care.
Typically, a time-poor man with a big job becomes neglectful about his weight and his activity levels.
Over time, he grows heavier and more sedentary. This continues for years as he imperceptibly moves into a pre-diabetic state.
Around middle age, he silently drifts over the line into diabetes type 2, a metabolic condition influenced by both lifestyle and genetic factors.
This is different to the far less common type 1 which people inherit rather than acquire.
While type 2 will raise his risk of cardiovascular and other diseases, his mates will reassure him that it is not disastrous because good treatment is available and sophisticated personal treatment is emerging.
Places such as Sydney's Garvan Institute are using genomic sequencing to try and develop tailored treatment strategies for individual patients.
 But this condition has complex ramifications and even when controlled on some measures, it may not be on others.
Our man, having passed into type 2 territory is now facing a 75 per cent greater risk of developing all forms of dementia compared to his peers who don't have this disorder.
There are so many ways this disorder can affect his brain that some researchers refer to the dementia that results as "diabetes type 3".
The brain His brain is the most metabolically active organ in his body. It constitutes about 2 per cent of his body weight but consumes between 10 and 20 per cent of his energy stores.
Diabetes will deprive it of fuel. It will affect the large vessels that bring blood to the head just as it will affect the small vessels that distribute blood in his brain.
It will also impair his brain cells' response to insulin, oxidative stress and inflammation.
Research last year showed fat can also leak into his brain with toxic effect.
In short, just as diabetes negatively affects his other bodily processes, so it negatively affects processes that strive to keep his brain healthy.
Within his actual brain cells, two processes could promote dementia, according to Mark Febbraio, professor and head of the Division of Diabetes and Metabolism at the Garvan.
First, with age, the ability of his brain cells to deal with debris is compromised.
Second, diabetes can cause proteins within these cells to fold incorrectly and become misshapen.
Because old cells can't dispose of these faulty proteins efficiently, they are left to aggregate into amyloid plaques.
He says the same amyloid development occurs in the pancreas.
But, maintaining a good lifestyle with lots of physical activity and excellent nutrition can slow the ageing of the cell and preserve its ability to deal with debris â€“ unless there is an overriding genetic predisposition to dementia.
"Everyone who lives long enough will experience some form of dementia," Febbraio says. "The question is how early it occurs and how rapidly it progresses."
Proteins His team currently has a drug in clinical trials for Alzheimer's in people with diabetes type 2.
It helps to refold misshapen proteins resulting in less debris in the cell.
The hope it that it will help delay the progression of their dementia.
Over the past decade, the link between diabetes and dementia has become the subject of intense international research.
Last week alone, two studies produced results that would concern anyone with the condition.
The first, a deep drill using only 40 people, was published in the journal Neurology .
It showed in just two years, people with diabetes type 2 experienced a marked drop in their ability to regulate blood flow in the brain.
This affected their cognitive and decision-making skills.
The Harvard authors explained that normal blood flow regulation allowed the brain to redistribute blood to areas that had increased activity while performing certain tasks.
Their participants were aged around 66 and half had been living with diabetes type 2 for about 13 years.
The other half didn't have the condition and at the start of the study scored some 55 points on their learning and memory tests. Two years later, their scores were largely unchanged.
The diabetics, however, began with scores around 46 and two years later were down to 41.
Higher levels of inflammation were also associated with greater decreases in regulation, even when diabetes type 2 was well controlled.
Overall, blood flow regulation in the brain was decreased by 65 percent in people with diabetes.
Activity The second study involved 430,000 people with new-onset diabetes type 2.
After following them for 12 years, the Taiwanese researchers found that as people experienced more complications from this condition, so their risk of dementia rose.
Published in the Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism , it is the first nationwide study to examine how the severity and progression of diabetes type 2 is related to dementia in people over 50.
Researchers tracked patients admitted to hospital or had at least three outpatient medical visits for dementia after receiving a diabetes diagnosis.
Almost 27,000 or 6.2 per cent developed dementia.
Those with complications such as nerve, kidney or eye damage were more likely to develop dementia.
There have been numerous other studies in the past 18 months including one from the Mayo Clinic which found the total brain volume of people who developed diabetes in middle age was, on average, 2.9 percent smaller than their peers.
The area of the brain that deals with the formation of long-term memories and spatial navigation, the hippocampus, was 4 per cent smaller.
And so it goes!
But can men step off this path or slow their progression along it?
Febbraio is a great advocate of activity.
For a start, he recommends men use the health app on their smart phone and aim to do 10,000 steps a day.
He's also an advocate of healthy eating.
While drugs can only control, not cure diabetes type 2, he says many men have been able to drift back over the line through diligent diet and activity.
